docs.abstract: Seeing an opportunity to have a larger impact on Silicon Valley and its business culture, Mr. Chenault plans to join the venture capital firm General Catalyst Partners.
docs.snippet: Seeing an opportunity to have a larger impact on Silicon Valley and its business culture, Mr. Chenault plans to join the venture capital firm General Catalyst Partners.
docs.lead_paragraph: Ever since Kenneth I. Chenault announced last fall that he would retire as chief executive of American Express, he has been fielding phone calls from companies looking to hire him.

headline.main: For His Next Act, Ken Chenault Turns His Focus on Silicon Valley
headline.print_headline: In Second Act, Venture Capital With a Twist

docs.abstract: Citing a member’s conflict in an earlier vote, the panel restored a standard making it easier to hold a company to account for franchisees’ practices.
docs.snippet: Citing a member’s conflict in an earlier vote, the panel restored a standard making it easier to hold a company to account for franchisees’ practices.
docs.lead_paragraph: First, it reversed an Obama-era rule helping workers challenge the labor practices of big chains. On Monday, the National Labor Relations Board reversed its reversal.

headline.main: Labor Board’s Do-Over Leaves an Obama-Era Rule Intact
headline.print_headline: A Labor-Friendly Rule Is Revived Amid Conflict

docs.abstract: The state’s highest court made it much harder for companies like Uber to classify workers as contractors rather than employees.
docs.snippet: The state’s highest court made it much harder for companies like Uber to classify workers as contractors rather than employees.
docs.lead_paragraph: In a ruling with potentially sweeping consequences for the so-called gig economy, the California Supreme Court on Monday made it much more difficult for companies to classify workers as independent contractors rather than employees.

headline.main: Gig Economy Business Model Dealt a Blow in California Ruling
headline.print_headline: Gig Economy Dealt a Blow By a Ruling In California

docs.abstract: The president aims to peel back labor protections and curb the power of government unions, which assailed the actions.
docs.snippet: The president aims to peel back labor protections and curb the power of government unions, which assailed the actions.
docs.lead_paragraph: Seizing on a longtime ambition of many Republicans, President Trump on Friday overhauled rules affecting at least two million federal workers, making it easier to fire them and rolling back the workplace role of their unions.

headline.main: Trump Moves to Ease the Firing of Federal Workers
headline.print_headline: Trump Targets Federal Workers In Orders Curbing Protections

docs.abstract: A growing number of state and local laws ban an employer practice that is said to perpetuate pay bias. But some researchers say the move may be counterproductive.
docs.snippet: A growing number of state and local laws ban an employer practice that is said to perpetuate pay bias. But some researchers say the move may be counterproductive.
docs.lead_paragraph: Laws prohibiting employers from asking job candidates about their past compensation before making a salary offer are gaining momentum, aimed at reducing pay disparities and other obstacles confronting women and minorities.

headline.main: If a Law Bars Asking Your Past Salary, Does It Help or Hurt?
headline.print_headline: Bans on Asking  About Past Pay  Can Backfire

docs.abstract: State media have hinted that Beijing could weaponize its consumers in a trade war. But American brands are popular in China — and Chinese workers make many of their products.
docs.snippet: State media have hinted that Beijing could weaponize its consumers in a trade war. But American brands are popular in China — and Chinese workers make many of their products.
docs.lead_paragraph: TAICANG, China — If China calls for a boycott of American goods, Chinese workers like David Xu could be in trouble.

headline.main: In a Trade War, China Might Boycott U.S. Goods. That Could Backfire.
headline.print_headline: A Boycott by China? It Could Backfire

byline.original: By Sui-Lee Wee and Zhang Tiantian

docs.abstract: Speaking at a high-profile forum in China, the country’s top leader addressed the growing conflict with the United States over tariffs and trade.
docs.snippet: Speaking at a high-profile forum in China, the country’s top leader addressed the growing conflict with the United States over tariffs and trade.
docs.lead_paragraph: BOAO, China — President Xi Jinping on Tuesday portrayed China as committed to opening its economy as he presented an alternative vision to President Trump’s calls for tariffs and restricting trade, urging “dialogue rather than confrontation.”

headline.main: Xi Jinping Urges Dialogue, Not Confrontation, After Trump Seeks Tariffs
headline.print_headline: China Leader Says Dialogue Can Resolve Tariffs Rift

docs.abstract: Thousands of electronics enthusiasts flooded the trade show to see the latest devices, but the darling of the event was the artificial intelligence software that helps these products run.
docs.snippet: Thousands of electronics enthusiasts flooded the trade show to see the latest devices, but the darling of the event was the artificial intelligence software that helps these products run.
docs.lead_paragraph: On an initial walk-through, this year’s CES electronics trade show was reminiscent of years past. Thousands of tech and gadget enthusiasts flooded the Las Vegas Convention Center for the four-day event, which began on Tuesday, to see the newest electronics that are being introduced on the market.

headline.main: CES 2018: What the Gadget Fest Looks Like in ‘the Year of A.I.’

byline.original: By Whitney Richardson and Brian X. Chen

docs.abstract: The Mate 10 Pro from Huawei, the Chinese manufacturer, has a great camera and better battery life than competitors. But American carriers aren’t selling it.
docs.snippet: The Mate 10 Pro from Huawei, the Chinese manufacturer, has a great camera and better battery life than competitors. But American carriers aren’t selling it.
docs.lead_paragraph: There’s a smartphone that the United States does not want you to buy. It’s called the Mate 10 Pro, and it’s made by Huawei, a Chinese manufacturer that the American government has long suspected of committing espionage for China.

headline.main: Meet the $800 Smartphone That You Probably Won’t Buy
headline.print_headline: Trust Issues Cloud Future of $800 Smartphone

docs.abstract: The troubled company continued selling investments to middle class Chinese despite Beijing’s debt crackdown — and the offers still appeal to many.
docs.snippet: The troubled company continued selling investments to middle class Chinese despite Beijing’s debt crackdown — and the offers still appeal to many.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Less than a month after it was seized by the Chinese government, Anbang Insurance Group, the giant conglomerate, is once again offering small investors “you snooze, you lose” investment opportunities — your money back, guaranteed.

headline.main: Anbang Was Seized by China. Now, It Has a Deal for You.
headline.print_headline: Despite a Crackdown by Beijing, Anbang Is Still Pitching Risky Investments

byline.original: By Sui-Lee Wee and Zhang Tiantian
